item.title: Unit Testing with Mocks
item.description: When unit testing classes that have followed SOLID principles, we often find classes take on the responsibility of a co-ordinator rather than implementing any specific logic themselves. When testing these classes it makes perfect sense to use mocks (e.g. the Moq library) to control the dependencies being co-ordinated. However, I sometimes see instances where people have misunderstood how these mocks work and why the test ends up not testing what it appears to.

item.title: Service Evolution with Consumer Driven Contracts and Pact
item.description: In a microservices architecture with a suite of inter-dependent services, ensuring fast feedback when API changes cause incompatibility becomes a key problem. Any time that incompatible services are deployed to an environment you will have caused a preventable outage that should be detected as part of your usual Continuous Integration solution. At dunnhumby, we use a squad based approach to application development which sees small ‘vertical’ teams form with team members representing all of the ‘horizontals’, such as API, UI and QA.
